Composite oxide catalysts have been widely studied in numerous fields. Species with different valences are responsible for different effect on activity. In this study, a battery of catalysts, of which support material are differently proportional phases of TiO2 by adjusting the amount of Sn and of which loading composition is MnCuOx, were synthesized. It is found that the doping of Sn could be in favor of the transformation from anatase TiO2 to rutile TiO2 at lower temperature, could enlarge the specific surface area and generate more oxygen vacancies, which could accelerate the oxidation of NO to NO2, beneficial for the “Fast-SCR” reaction at low temperature. In addition, Cu species prefer to exist in form of Cu0 on rutile TiO2., improving the reductive ability of catalysts and getting more monodentate nitrite species involved into the reaction. To recap, this study provides a theoretical guidance for preparation and exploration of Cu-based catalysts. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Rutile TiO2 Transition temperature Sn Cu-based catalyst NH3-SCR Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Composite oxide catalyst has been widely applied in myriads of fields, such as thermal catalysis, photocatalysis and electrocatalysis. In composite oxide catalysts, different components could introduce different properties and the interaction between the components could introduce additional properties, which enable composite oxide catalyst to hold a promising future [1–5]. Designing and optimizing of composite oxide catalysts are not only beneficial to the preparation of the cost-effective environmentally-friendly catalyst, but also could provide guidance for exploration of catalyst mechanism. Cu-based catalysts manifest outstanding performance of NH3-SCR activity at low temperature [5–8]. Cu elements with different valences play different roles at NH3-SCR activity. Cu2+ is in possession of strong oxidative ability [8–11], while Cu+ possesses oxidative and reductive ability at the same time [5,6,9]. It is worth emphasizing that Cu is delicately aimed at the selective reduction of NO [10]. However, the preparation of copper-base catalyst by calcination in the air makes the copper ion with low valence hard to form, restricting the application of metallic copper. In order to further explore the catalytic potential of Cu-based catalysts, element doping is a common strategy [12–14]. The electron transfer between Cu and introduced element could contribute the valence transformation of Cu and increased oxygen vacancies, thus enhancing the catalytic performance of Cu-based catalysts. Additionally, previous studies have shown that the highly dispersed Cu species could usually exhibit a high catalytic activity [15–17]. The preparation of Cu-based catalysts into supported catalysts could realize the high dispersion and introduce additional properties through the interaction between carrier and active species. TiO2 has been extensively studied as a support material in NH3-SCR and confirmed as a promising material by virtue of its low-toxicity, low cost and thermal stability [7,18-20]. TiO2 has anatase, brookite and rutile phases. However, anatase and rutile are more stable. Anatase TiO2 has attracted more attention drawing upon its lower phase transition temperature, higher specific surface area and more acid sites compared with rutile phase TiO2 [21,22]. Rutile phase TiO2 holds merits of its (110) plane possessing stronger reductive ability and being inclined to act as reductive sites [23,24], which is conductive for formation of Cu0. However, the phase transition from anatase to rutile requires higher temperature, and the specific surface area of rutile TiO2 is usually small [22]. Researches have proved that doping metals could adjust the phase transition temperature [25,26]. On top of that, doping metals could cause lattice distortion, resulting in improvement of specific surface area, which renders rutile phase TiO2 a potential applicant of NH3-SCR catalyst. In this study, catalyst of Sn-doped rutile TiO2 with MnCuOx loaded on was prepared. This catalyst showed greater NH3-SCR activity below 200 °C. It is found that the doping of Sn could accelerate the transformation from anatase TiO2 to rutile TiO2 at low temperature, enlarge the specific surface area of rutile TiO2 and generate more oxygen vacancies, promoting the oxidation of NO to NO2, which is favorable to “Fast-SCR” reaction at low temperature. Moreover, Cu species is inclined to exist in form of Cu0 on rutile TiO2, thus enhancing the reductive ability of catalysts, and getting more monodentate nitrite species involved into the reaction. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials Ethanol was purchased from Xilong Science Co., Ltd. SnCl4⋅5H2O, 50% Mn(NO3)2 solution was purchased from Macklin Biochemical Co., Ltd. All chemicals used are AR grade. 2.2 Synthesis of support material All chemicals used in this procedure are analytical reagent grade if without any specific notification. Stannic chloride (SnCl4⋅5H2O) and Titanium (IV) butoxide (TBT=Ti(OC4H9)4, Aldrich, CR) are used as the precursor salts of SnO2 and TiO2 respectively. This synthesis method is the joint of sol-gel and hydrothermal, like our previous work [27]. At first, 8 mL TBT was added into 34 mL absolute ethanol and 2 mL glacial acetic. Then, the mixture was vigorously stirred for 20 min under room temperature. After that, diluted nitric acid (12 %) was added into the mixture in dropwise until the pH=3, followed by addition of 4 mL deionized water and further 10 min stir. SnCl4⋅5H2O was added into the solution in light of the molar ratio of Ti to Sn equating 3:1, 20:1 and 60:1 in the wake of 30 min aging. After going through another 15 min stirring, the Sn dopant was completely dissolved. In order of comparison, two comparison samples without any addition of SnCl4⋅5H2O were prepared in the same way as well. After further aging of 24 h, these mixtures were transferred to steel autoclave with Teflon liner and reacted at 180 °C for 24 h. At last, once the hydrothermal treatment finished, these precipitates were collected, washed by deionized water and absolute ethanol, dried in an oven overnight, grinded into powder as well as annealed at 500 °C for 7 h, while one of the comparison samples annealed at 700 °C for 7 h. 2.3 Synthesis of catalyst Wetness impregnation method is applied for the preparation of catalyst. Mn(NO3)2 and Cu(NO3)2 are precursor salts of MnOx and CuOx. First, 1 g support material from the last step was added into deionized water. Then fixed content of Mn(NO3)2 and Cu(NO3)2 of which amount is 10 % of the support material and the molar ratio of Mn to Cu is 1:1 were added. After being stirred for a while, they were further stirred at oil bath until the water vapored. After calcination under 500 °C for 7 h, the catalysts were successfully synthesized. These products are denoted as MnCuOx /TiO2–500, MnCuOx /T3S1–500, MnCuOx /T20S1–500, MnCuOx /T60S1–500, MnCuOx /TiO2–700, where the T represents for TiO2, S stands for SnO2, the numbers after T and S mean the simplest molar ratio between Ti and Sn, while the number connected with the hyphen represents for the annealing temperature of support material. 2.4 Characterizations X-ray diffraction (XRD) was carried out on under a condition of 40 kV tube voltage and 30 mA tube current. The Cu target Kα rays were used to explore the crystal structure of the photocatalyst through a ray diffractometer (DX-2700AX), X-ray diffraction patterns of samples at 10 o − 80 o were recorded. The N2 adsorption-desorption curve was tested on the Micromeritics ASAP2020 analytical instrument. The samples were pretreated at 300 °C for 3 h. The pore size distribution and specific surface area of catalysts were calculated by using Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) method and Brunauer-Emmet-Teller (BET) equation. The temperature programmed reduction of hydrogen (H2-TPR) and the temperature programmed desorption of ammonia (NH3-TPD) were tested on Finesorb-3010 automatic chemisorption apparatus of Zhejiang Fantai Instrument Co., Ltd. For H2-TPR. 25 mg of each sample was pretreated at 110 °C and under N2 atmosphere for 1 h, followed by cooling down to room temperature, at which the H2-Ar mixture was then flooded into as reduction gas, and adsorbed were H2-Ar on samples for 30 min to reach adsorption equilibrium. At last, the samples were tested as the temperature was raised to 800 °C at a heating rate of 10 °C⋅min−1, and the data of H2-TPR was collected by thermal conductivity detector (TCD). For NH3-TPD, 50 mg of each sample was pretreated at 300 °C for 1 h under He atmosphere and then samples all cooled down to room temperature. Then the gas was switched to NH3, at ramp of 10 mL⋅min−1, for 1 h adsorption. After absorption completed, the He flushing pipeline was then passed through for another 30 min and the temperature rose from room temperature to target temperature at a rate of 10 °C⋅min−1. The data of NH3-TPD was collected by thermal conductivity detector (TCD). X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) test was performed on Thermo Fisher Scientific ESCALAB 250XI electron spectrometer, and C1s (284.8 eV) was used for calibration. Nicolet iS50 FT-IR spectrometer was used to collect in situ diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectra (In situ DRIFTS). The MCT detector resolution of the spectrometer was 4 cm−1, and the scanning times were 32. A certain amount of the catalyst was filled in the reaction cell, and it was pretreated with N2 at 110 °C (300 °C for NH3 adsorption-desorption test) for 30 min to purge the water molecules and weakly adsorbed gas on the surface. The background spectrum was collected once the temperature reached to 30 °C, at which the N2 was cut off and reaction gasses were turned on for 1 h adsorption. Finally, the temperature was raised to a certain point at the reaction gas atmosphere, and the infrared spectrum of the sample were collected. 2.5 Activity test The activity of the catalysts was tested in a fixed-bed reactor and the testing condition as follows: NO = NH3 = 500 ppm, O2 = 5 vol%, SO2 = 50 ppm (when used), H2O = 5 vol% (when used), GHSV = 60,000 h − 1. 100 mg (40–60 mesh) samples was put in a quartz tube, and pretreated at 110 °C under N2 atmosphere for 30 min. After cooling down to room temperature, the reaction gas was passed into the catalyst for 1 h adsorption and then the temperature rose from room temperature to a certain temperature at a step of 25 °C. The concentrations of NO, N2O and NO2 at different target temperature were detected by FGA10 flue gas analyzer. The calculation formula of NO conversion was as follows: (1) NO conversion = [ NO ] in − [ NO ] out [ NO ] in × 100 % 3 Results and discussion 3.1 XRD results The Fig. 1 , XRD patterns of prepared catalysts, reveals the constitution of samples, and Table. 1 shows the percentage of phase constitution. In the sample MnCuOx /TiO2–500, its main peaks are in line with anatase TiO2 (PDF#99–0008). For the sample MnCuOx /TiO2–700, its main peaks accord with rutile TiO2 (PDF#99–0090). It can be seen in Table.1, as the decline of Sn addition in the ratio of Ti/Sn from 3:1, 20:1 to 60:1, the content of rutile phase declines as well, from 100 % to 4.7 %, leading to the co-existence of anatase and rutile phases in samples MnCuOx /T20S1–500 and MnCuOx /T60S1–500. Enlarged, the region between 20 o to 30 o shows the changes of (110) and (101) planes. All of these peaks belonging to (110) and (101) planes in samples whose support material contain Sn broaden a little bit and shift towards lower angle. It is known that the ion radius of Sn4+ (0.069 nm) is larger than that of Ti4+ (0.061 nm) [28]. The Bragg equation, 2 d sin θ = n λ , explains this phenomenon and proves that the Sn was successfully incorporated into the lattice of TiO2, causing lattice distortion. The broaden peaks and less peak intensities are signs of the decline of crystallinity, generating more oxygen vacancies, which is in favor for NO conversion [3]. There is no any sign of MnOx or CuOx. It is quite possible that these oxides disperse well on the surface of catalysts, or their content is too low to detect. 3.2 BET analysis N2 adsorption-desorption experiment was applied to measure their specific surface area and pore size distribution. All the data are summarized in Table. 2 . The surface area change is MnCuOx /T20S1–500 > MnCuOx /T60S1–500 > MnCuOx /T3S1–500 > MnCuOx /TiO2–500 > MnCuOx /TiO2–700. The surface area of pure anatase TiO2 is greater than that of pure rutile phase TiO2, which accords with the well-established fact as previous literatures reported [26,27]. Owing to the incorporation of Sn into the support material, their specific surface area rises in consequence of the lattice distortion. With proper proportion of anatase and rutile phases mixed, the catalyst can reach to greater specific surface area, such as the sample MnCuOx /T20S1–500 and MnCuOx /T60S1–500. Fig. 2 (a) illustrates that all of these samples are IV isotherms, classified by IUPAC and a significant hallmark of mesoporous materials, with H3 hysteresis loops. However, the loop in MnCuOx /TiO2–700, of which support material is pure rutile phase TiO2, is not obvious and locates at a point where the relative pressure is pretty high, showing that this catalyst is hard to form complete pore structure with such small surface area. On the contrary, with the incorporation of Sn, the surface physiochemical properties of catalyst, MnCuOx /T3S1–500, of which support material is modified rutile phase TiO2, is improved, being able to form complete pore structure. Owing to the reactants have to realize adsorption and activation on active site, the pore structures are conducive to the adsorption and gas diffusion [29]. In the meantime, the exhibition of their pore size distribution also proves their homogeneous pore size and good dispersity, except for catalyst MnCuOx /TiO2–700. 3.3 NH3-TPD and H2-TPR results The amount of surface acidity plays a crucial role in the activity to some extent. Therefore, NH3-TPD was applied to fulfill the measurement. It can be seen that in Fig. 3 (a), one main peak spanning from around 50 °C to 400 °C emerges at all samples. This peak can be deconvoluted into four peaks, and their peak area, which could be used to reflect the amount of acid, are summarized in Table. 3 . The peak a, mainly lying at 100 °C, belongs to physically absorbed NH3 [30]. The second peak b, situated at 150 °C, the low temperature region, is ascribed into weak acid [30,31]. The third peak c, at the mid temperature, from 200 °C-300 °C, falls into the category of the mid-strong acid [30–32]. The fourth peak, normally at high temperature, over 300 °C, is irrelevant to the activity temperature that we tested next, so there is no need to elaborate this peak. As the addition of Sn, the content of rutile TiO2 changes as well, so does the specific surface area. The greater surface area could provide more acid sites and their sequences of amount of acid, proportional to peak area [7], fit with the trend of surface area change. Since the position of desorption peak could reflect the acidic strength [7], it is evident that the position of three types of acid shift to lower temperature as the increase of rutile TiO2 content, which means stronger acidic strength at lower temperature. As previous literatures report [7,33,34], for MnCu-base catalyst, the increase of amount of acid and strength could improve the SCR activity. In this work, the amount of acid sites on MnCuOx/T20S1–500 is the most among all of them, so its activity could be the best among them. However, the position of desorption temperature of MnCuOx/T3S1–500 demonstrates its stronger NH3 desorption at low temperature, which could enhance its SCR activity at low temperature. More details about the SCR activity analysis will be put in catalyst activity test. To determine the type of oxides on the surface of catalysts and assess the redox ability of catalysts, temperature programmed reduction of hydrogen (H2-TPR) was applied to serve the course. The Fig. 3(b) shows that all catalysts have two main analogous peaks. The first peak can be deconvoluted into two peaks. The peak Cu (II), around 150 °C, could be ascribed to Cu2+ to Cu+ [7,9], while the second one, peak Cu (I), could be assigned to Cu+ to Cu [8,9]. The third one, peak Mn (IV), could be deemed as the direct reduction process of Mn4+ to Mn2+, which may be caused by the rapid hydrogen spillover from the reduced Cu to the interfacial MnOx [35,36]. It is worthy noticing that the reduction temperature of copper oxides decreases as the content of rutile TiO2 and their specific surface area change. It is reasonable to deduce that the greater specific surface area makes the loading constitution disperse better and is helpful with the decrease of reduction temperature, which could enhance the activity at low temperature. The information about their H2 consumption is listed in Table 4 . Since the Cu2+ is reduced to Cu+ at first, then the reduced Cu+ with original Cu+ reacts with H2 later, the H2 consumption of peak Cu (I) represents the amount of Cu ions. The percentage of Cu+ and Mn4+ change is MnCuOx /T3S1–500 > MnCuOx /TiO2–700 > MnCuOx /T20S1–500 > MnCuOx /T60S1–500 > MnCuOx /TiO2–500. It can be concluded that the rutile phase of TiO2 is favorable for the formation of Cu+ and Mn4+. Due to the amount of added precursor salt, Cu(NO3)2, is same, the H2 consumption of peak Cu (I) is supposed to be equal as well if all copper exists in form of ions. However, the value of peak Cu (I) at MnCuOx /TiO2–700 and MnCuOx /T3S1–500 are the least, implying the existence of Cu0. The sequence of amount of metallic copper goes as MnCuOx /T3S1–500 > MnCuOx /TiO2–700 > MnCuOx /T20S1–500 > MnCuOx /T60S1–500 > MnCuOx /TiO2–500. It can be concluded that the rutile phase of TiO2, modified or not, is favorable for the formation Cu species with lower valence. With the existence of Cu0, whose reductive ability is stronger than Cu+, the activity of catalysts could be enhanced. Further proof for the percentage of each metal valence state will be provided in XPS analysis. 3.4 XPS analysis Investigating the valence of each chemical element is helpful with understanding of the electron transfer between elements. The main results are showed in Fig. 4 and Table 5 . Fig. 4(a) shows that two main characteristic peaks belonging to Cu 2p3/2 and Cu 2p1/2 spin orbitals are situated at 932.0 eV and 952.0 eV [35], and they can be deconvoluted into two peaks. Peaks related to Cu2+ appear at 934.1 eV ∼ 935.3 eV. The shake-up satellites around 943.0 eV attest the existence of Cu2+ [7]. The first peaks located at 932.2 eV ∼ 933.4 eV at all catalysts are difficult to be identified on the grounds that Cu+ and Cu0 respond at similar binding energy [37]. To distinguish them, we further analyzed the Auger electron kinetic energy of Cu elements. Fig. 4(b), the Cu LMM XAES spectra, exhibit two broad asymmetry peaks at each catalyst. Peaks at 913.7 eV ∼ 917.2 eV signal the appearance of Cu+ species at each sample [38–40]. Peaks at 917.2 eV ∼ 919.7 eV not only imply the existence of Cu0, whose Auger electron kinetic energy is 918.0 eV [37,41], but also co-exist with CuO, whose Auger electron kinetic energy is 918.4 eV [42,43]. Based on the H2-TPR, XPS and Cu LMM results, it is easy to calculate the percentage of Cu+ and Cu2+, respectively, then acquire the percentage of Cu0. The Fig. S2 shows that the content of Cu0 increases as the ratio of rutile/anatase ratio increases. It is reasonable to conclude that the rutile TiO2 is beneficial for the formation of Cu0. As for Mn species, the Fig. 4(c) shows two main peaks corresponding to Mn 2p3/2 and Mn 2p1/2 spin orbitals appear at 638 eV-645 eV and 649–656 eV, respectively. Each peak can be deconvoluted into three peaks. The first peak, 640.6 eV ∼ 641.0 eV, is attributed to Mn2+ [7]. The second one emerging at 641.9 eV ∼ 642.9 eV belongs to Mn3+ [44]. The last one peak, located at around 643.9 eV ∼644.3 eV, is assigned to Mn4+ [45]. From Table. 5, the content of Mn4+ increases as the content of rutile TiO2 increase, accompanying with the decline of Cu2+, which implies the redox equilibrium, Cu+ + Mn4+ ↔ Cu2+ + Mn3+ [7,46],occurs at the synthesis process. It indicates that Mn4+ is the main species on the surface. As literature reports, more surface Mn4+ ions could increase the oxygen vacancies to promote the adsorption, activation and migration of oxygen in the gas phase [36]. Since the redox cycle of Mn4+ can promote the "Fast-SCR" reaction at low temperature [47,48], the activity of catalyst with higher Mn4+ might be improved. The peak of O 1s spectra, Fig. 4(d), can be deconvoluted into two peaks. The peak at relatively lower binding energy, around 529.4 eV ∼ 529.8 eV [16,49,50]and labelled as OL, is deemed as lattice oxygen. The other one at higher binding energy, both at 530.9 eV ∼ 531.4 eV [20,51] and denoted as OC, is reckoned as chemisorbed oxygen. The chemisorbed oxygen is more vital than lattice oxygen in facilitating NH3-SCR activity by drawing upon its high mobility, not only promoting the absorption of reactants, NH3 and NOx, but also accelerating the oxidation of NO to NO2, which is a crucial step for "Fast-SCR" reaction at low temperature. Table. 5 clearly shows that the ratio of chemisorbed oxygen increases as the content of rutile TiO2 and Mn4+, which can enhance the activity of catalyst. However, with the low specific surface area, low amount of acid and loading constitution in clusters on the surface, the activity of MnCuOx/TiO2–700 might not as good as that of others. Taking the change of Cu+, Mn4+, Cu2+, Mn3+ and OC into consideration, it is safe to say that the rutile TiO2 is favorable for formation of the Mn4+, Cu0 and Cu+. What's more, due to the addition of Sn, their surface area is modified, beneficial for highly dispersed species. Of importance is that the redox equilibrium, Cu+ + Mn4+ ↔ Cu2+ + Mn3+, occurring at the synthesis process, could provide more oxygen vacancies for getting more chemisorbed oxygen involved to enhance the activity [7,8,46]. In addition, Fig. S3 (a) and Fig. S3 (b) demonstrates that Ti and Sn elements exist in form of Ti4+ and Sn4+ [28]. 3.5 Catalysts activity test Fig. 5 (a) shows the activity trend of catalysts from 100 °C to 300 °C. Due to the low specific surface area, loading composition accumulated in clusters and low amount of acid sites, the catalysts, MnCuOx/TiO2–700 and MnCuOx/TiO2–500 pale in comparison with other three catalysts at activity during the whole test. First, the trend of activity over 200 °C, MnCuOx/T20S1–500 > MnCuOx/T60S1–500 > MnCuOx/T3S1–500 > MnCuOx/TiO2–500 > MnCuOx/TiO2–700, meets with the trend of their specific surface area and the amount of mid-strong acid, meaning that higher specific surface area is conductive for gas diffusion and the greater acid amount is also the impetus behind the activity. However, below the 200 °C, the activity of MnCuOx/T3S1–500 catalyst is superior to the rest of catalysts, reaching to 87.65% at 200 °C. This trend fits with the change of Cu0 and Mn4+. There is no doubt that Cu+ is favorable for the activity due to its reductive ability. In addition, its acidic strength is stronger at low temperature region, which is another reason that its activity is better than that of others at this point. It can be reasonable to believe that Sn doping induces the phase content change, then the phase of support material causes these differences. To determine the effect of metallic copper, whose reductive ability is stronger than Cu+, we had copper ions on MnCuOx/T20S1–500, MnCuOx/T60S1–500 and MnCuOx/T3S1–500 reduced to metallic copper under H2 atmosphere at a fixed temperature based on the results of H2-TPR and denoted as MnCu(R)Ox/T20S1–500, MnCu(R)Ox/T60S1–500 and MnCu(R)Ox/T3S1–500, where (R) means reduced copper. More details about this process is elucidated in supplementary material. The Fig. 5(b) shows that their activity under 200 °C all improved compared with themselves earlier. The Cu0 with its strong reductive ability could serve as adsorption sites for NO2 and promote the NO2 dissociation [52,53]. This proves that metallic copper does level up the catalyst's reductive ability, thus improving their activity under 200 °C. Fig. 5(c) can indirectly reflect the N2 selectivity, since N2O is the byproduct of non-selective oxidation of NH3 [46]. Below the mid-temperature, the concentration of N2O of catalysts, MnCuOx/T3S1–500, MnCuOx/T20S1–500 and MnCuOx/T60S1–500, are around 50 ppm, which is an indication of excellent N2 selectivity (more than 90%) [46]. It is because that the selective reduction of NO by metallic copper at low temperature could prevent N2 from being over oxidized. Since the 200 °C is the watershed where activity changes and catalyst MnCuOx/T3S1–500 culminates, then we chose 200 °C as testing temperature for their resistance to H2O and SO2. The Fig. 5(d) shows that as the increase content of rutile TiO2 and Cu0, the activity change variance gets less as well during the water involved and water along with SO2 involved (specific data change is available in supplementary material). It can be concluded that the rutile TiO2 and Cu0 improve its resistance to H2O and SO2. However, after cut off H2O and SO2, their activity recovers little. The difficulty of decomposition of sulfate under 200 °C is culpable for this phenomenon. 3.6 In-situ drifts analysis All of these samples were tested by in-situ DRIFTS characterization to investigate the formation and transformation of surface species and intermediates, their reaction pathway and reaction mechanism. Two main catalysts, MnCuOx/T3S1–500, MnCuOx/T20S1–500, are elaborated at this section, while the rest of them are put in the supplementary material. 3.6.1 NH3 adsorption-desorption To precisely determine the type of acid on catalysts, in situ DRIFTS NH3 adsorption-desorption is the way to serve the course. Fig. 6 distinctly shows the resemblance and difference between samples. After saturated with NH3, both catalysts display bands germane to acid sites. First of all, 1357, 1542, 1635 cm−1 emerge at both catalysts. Bands at 1357 cm−1 and 1542 cm−1 could be attributed to bending vibrations of NH bonds of coordinated -NH2 [54] or -NH2 species [55], which is an active intermediate generated by oxidation of NH3 absorbed on surface of catalyst. The band at 1635 cm−1, which only shows its presence at very low temperature, belongs to the coordinated NH3 on Lewis acid sites [56]. As for sample MnCuOx/T3S1–500, one band attributed to coordinated NH3 on Lewis acid sites locates at 1284 cm−1 [28] with higher thermal stability in comparison with the species at 1635 cm−1. However, MnCuOx/T20S1–500, shows three more species of coordinated NH3 on Lewis acid sites at 1145 cm−1 [57], 1241 cm−1 [28] appearing at low temperature while disappearing as the temperature rises, and 1187 cm−1 shows the same trend with 1284 cm−1. As to the rest of catalysts, in Fig S5, a noteworthy nuance is the band 1284 cm−1 only emerges at MnCuOx/T3S1–500 and there is no sign of 1241 cm−1 and 1145 cm−1. As reported, the doping of Sn4+ could introduce more Lewis acid sites [58,59]. In this work, the Sn addition modifies the surface area, improving the amount of acid sites, and regulated the phase content, which determines the type of adsorbed NH3. When the rutile TiO2 dominates, the band at 1284 cm−1 emerges. When the anatase TiO2 dominates, only bands at 1241 cm−1 and 1145 cm−1 appear. There is no any sign of bands of Brønsted acid sites. Till now, we can conclude that all catalysts only provide Lewis acid sites. 3.6.2 NO+O2 adsorption-desorption The formation of NOx is crucial in NH3-SCR process, NO+O2 adsorption can provide us with information about the species. In Fig. 7 , below 100 °C, bridge nitrate occurs at 1234 cm−1 [60] and 1218 cm−1 [45] in two of them, respectively. Then with their vanishment comes the bidentate nitrate (typeⅠ) at 1288 cm−1 [61]. It is reasonable to believe that this kind of bridge nitrate transforms into bidentate nitrate. The other common ground shared by them is the band at 1616 cm−1 and 1612 cm−1 assigned to gaseous NO2 occur at low temperature and vanish with the rise of temperature [54,55,57]. Reportedly, NO is easy to be oxidized by chemisorbed oxygen. Meantime, a new type of nitrate, deemed as bidentate nitrate (typeⅠ), comes into presence at 1573 cm−1 and 1569 cm−1 [51,61,62], respectively. While the nitrate at 1573 cm−1 fades away after 250 °C, the other one can last until 300 °C. It indicates that the rutile TiO2 is favorable for the decomposition of this nitrate at low temperature, thus it enhances its activity below 200 °C. The band at 1457 cm−1, monodentate nitrate [61], exists at both catalysts. A new band at 1515 cm−1, monodentate nitrite species [57,63], only emerges at the catalyst MnCuOx/T3S1–500. Same phenomenon can be found at Fig. S6 (c), MnCuOx/TiO2–700, whose support material is pure rutile phase. Even though its intensity is too weak, which can be explained by its restriction to least specific surface area, this type of nitrite is only found at it. It can be explained by the strong reductive ability of metallic copper. With the involvement of this monodentate nitrite, one of the active mediates, below 200 °C, the activity of MnCuOx/T3S1–500 improves. 3.6.3 NH3+NO+O2 adsorption By exposing catalysts at the simultaneous existence of three reaction gas during the whole testing temperature, we can learn more about the variations among species, then propose a possible reaction mechanism. The Fig. 8 (a) shows that there is only one band relevant to NH3 species at 1353 cm−1, bending vibrations of NH bonds in coordinated -NH2, while all bands belonging to nitrate and nitrite emerge and some bands’ intensities have been enhanced, indicating that there is either a competitive absorption between coordinated NH3 species and NOx species or the bands related to acid sites are overlapped by other NOx relative bands. The change illustrates some facts. The presence of 1353 cm−1 band through the whole temperature demonstrates that -NH2 is the main active species. At the low temperature region, below 150 °C, the existence of bridge nitrate (1234 cm−1), monodentate nitrate (1457 cm−1), and NO2 (1616 cm−1) proves that the reaction proceeds in “Fast-SCR” and Langmuir-Hinshelwood (L-H) mechanism at the same time. At higher temperature, there are only bands pertaining to the nitrate species, indicating that Langmuir-Hinshelwood (L-H) mechanism dominates. As for Fig. 8(b), most of bands resemble those of Fig. 8(a), except for two significant differences. One of them is that two bands at low wavenumber, 1149 cm−1, less intense below 200 °C in comparison with Fig. 6(b), and 1187 cm−1, only emerging at high temperature, meaning these two NH3 competitive edge of relative species on adsorption. The other one is this catalyst lacks a nitrite species at 1515 cm−1, emerging throughout the whole process of reaction on catalyst MnCuOx/T3S1–500. Without the active intermediate nitrite species in the reaction its activity is lower below 200 °C. While with more coordinated NH3 species participated in over 200 °C its activity outweighs the other one. 3.7 Reaction mechanism The analysis of in situ spectra provides information about reaction mechanism. To begin with, the NH3 gas can easily absorb on the Lewis acid sites and then be oxidized by the chemisorbed oxygen to form -NH2, a very active intermediate which is crucial in NH3-SCR process. For the gaseous NO, part of the gas will be absorbed on the surface at low temperature, oxidized by chemisorbed oxygen to form gaseous NO2 and get involved into the reaction with -NH2 in "Fast-SCR" mechanism. The rest of the NO gas reacts with O2 to generate different kinds of nitrates and nitrites, which maintain as the temperature rises and participate in the reaction with -NH2 at high temperature in l-H mechanism. These two processes can be expressed as following equations: “Fast-SCR” mechanism: (2) NH 3 ( g ) → Lewis acid sites NH 3 ( ad ) (3) NH 3 ( ad ) + O * → Lewis acid sites − NH 2 ( ad ) (4) NO ( g ) + O * ( chemisorbed oxygen ) → NO 2 ( g ) (5) NO 2 ( g ) + − NH 2 → N 2 + H 2 O L-H mechanism: (6) NH 3 ( g ) → Lewis acid sites NH 3 ( ad ) (7) NH 3 ( ad ) + O * → Lewis acid sites − NH 2 ( ad ) (8) NO ( g ) + O * ( chemisorbed oxygen ) → NO 2 ( ad ) (9) NO 2 ( ad ) + O * → * NO 3 − ( ad ) (10) NO 2 ( ad ) + O * + C u 0 → * NO 2 − ( ad ) (11) * NO 3 − ( ad ) / * NO 2 − ( ad ) + − NH 2 ( ad ) → N 2 + H 2 O 4 Conclusions By doping Sn into TiO2, a series of catalysts whose support material are different proportional anatase TiO2 and rutile TiO2 and whose loading component is MnCuOx were successfully synthesized. The doping of Sn could facilitate the transformation from anatase TiO2 to rutile TiO2 at lower temperature, introduce lattice distortion, enlarging the specific surface area and improving the dispersity of loading component, and produce more oxygen vacancies for the generation of more chemisorbed oxygen, promoting the oxidation of NO to NO2, which benefits “Fast-SCR” reaction at low temperature. The Cu species is found to tent to exist in form of Cu0 on the surface of rutile TiO2, which enhances the reductive ability of catalysts and leads to the formation of monodentate nitrite species to get involved into the reaction. This study provides a new strategy for preparation of rutile phase TiO2, metallic copper as well as establishes a profound understanding of impact of metallic copper on NH3-SCR activity. coredata.dc:description: Composite oxide catalysts have been widely studied in numerous fields. Species with different valences are responsible for different effect on activity. In this study, a battery of catalysts, of which support material are differently proportional phases of TiO2 by adjusting the amount of Sn and of which loading composition is MnCuOx, were synthesized. It is found that the doping of Sn could be in favor of the transformation from anatase TiO2 to rutile TiO2 at lower temperature, could enlarge the specific surface area and generate more oxygen vacancies, which could accelerate the oxidation of NO to NO2, beneficial for the “Fast-SCR” reaction at low temperature. In addition, Cu species prefer to exist in form of Cu0 on rutile TiO2., improving the reductive ability of catalysts and getting more monodentate nitrite species involved into the reaction. To recap, this study provides a theoretical guidance for preparation and exploration of Cu-based catalysts.
coredata.dc:title: Simultaneous regulation for phase transition of titanium dioxide and valence distribution of copper species on MnCuOx/TiSnOx
